results.title: Swimming with sharks = The Buddy factor [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: George Huang, Joanne Moore, Steve Alexander and Keystone Partners
results.brief_description: When Guy, a recent film-school graduate with big ideas, takes a job as assistant to major studio executive, Buddy Ackerman, he believes his ship has finally come in. Little does he know, however, that it is a slave ship, for his boss is indeed worse than a slave driver, delighting in abusing his new toy-boy. Guy struggles to push his idea for a script and feels he’s finally made it when Buddy congratulates him on a job well done. However, much to his chagrin, his conniving boss actually takes sole credit for the project, pushing Guy to his wit’s end. He breaks into Buddy’s Beverly Hills home and takes him hostage, then proceeds to torture him in a number of demeaning and horrifying ways. Cast includes: Kevin Spacey, Frank Whaley, Michelle Forbes, Benicio del Toro and Jerry Levine.

results.title: Swimming in the backyard
results.creator_credit: Polly Watkins, Beth Frey and Blackout Productions
results.brief_description: This short documentary was commissioned by SBS Independent as part of its ‘Australia by Numbers’ series about community life in various postcodes around Australia. This episode centres on the municipal pool in Prahran, an inner suburb of Melbourne. Every summer, since it was built in the 1960’s, the pool has been a magnet for a diverse range of locals who go there both to socialise and exercise. A constant over the years has been the pool’s two long serving managers, who know and are known by almost everyone.

results.title: Sweet victory: England vs All Black, Saturday November 27th., 1993.
results.brief_description: In November 1993, at the historic rugby ground at Twickenham, England faced the legendary All Blacks of New Zealand in a mighty contest. Having previously swept aside all comers on their tour of England, the All Blacks thrashed Scotland one week prior to the match with England. Led by Will Carling, for a record 36th. time, England’s new look side were very much the underdogs. Nevertheless, it was to be England’s day, and helped by the passionate support of a vocal home crowd, the All Blacks were defeated. Relive the many memorable moments of this historic match.

results.title: Grapes and wine: a family tradition
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Lance Milne is a third generation farmer in Nangiloc-Colignan. He and his wife Marina own a large vineyard in Nangiloc and diversified their business by purchasing one of Mildura’s oldest wineries, Château Mildura. They supply their own grapes and grow citrus. Lance is a passionate horticulturalist and is heavily involved in preserving the important history of wine growing in the Mildura region.

results.title: Sweet smell of success [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alexander Mackendrick, James Hill and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: This film noir has been well described as, ‘a rat trap of a film’, a compelling portrayal of corruption in which an unscrupulous small-time press agent, intent on clawing his way to the top, debases himself for the favours of a monster of a newspaper columnist. While it does not involve murder, the degree of manipulation and self deception is truly noir. Sidney Falco, the agent, is ultimately a more sympathetic figure because the cold bloodedness and self-righteous egomania of the columnist, J.J. Hunsecker, sets Falco’s faint glimmerings of self-disgust into relief. Susan Hunsecker, the object of her brother’s repressed incestuous desire, is the one figure who provides some moral bearings and delivers the retribution that J.J. fears. New York locations, aided by James Wong Howe’s night photography and Bernstein’s limpid jazz score, have never seemed bleaker. Featuring Burt Lancaster, Tony Curtis, Susan Harrison, Screenplay, Clifford Odets and Ernest Lehman from the novelette by Ernest Lehman.

results.title: Sweet sixteen
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Rebecca O'Brien, Alta Films, Tornasol Films, Road Movies and Sixteen Films
results.brief_description: From the same talented writer (Paul Laverty) and director (Ken Loach) team of “My name is Joe” fame, comes a well-made but similarly realistic and despairing film about the harsh life of a fifteen year-old Scottish youth. Liam (Martin Compston) wants a new life for his mother when she gets out of prison and foils plans by her boyfriend to smuggle drugs inside during a visit with he and his grandfather. After a severe beating by the boyfriend and being kicked out of home by his grandfather, Liam takes refuge at his sister Chantelle’s house (Annmarie Fulton). Liam and his best mate Pinball (William Ruane) try and raise some cash to buy a caravan for his mother on her release but the boys get involved with drug trafficking and gangsters, resulting in a series of events that are also their undoing. Winner of Best Screenplay Award Cannes Film Festival 2002. A UK/German/Spanish co-production.

results.title: Sweet love, bitter
results.creator_credit: Herbert Danska, Louis W Kellman, Lewis Jacobs and Film Three Productions
results.brief_description: Fictional chronicle depicting the last years of jazz musician’s Charlie ‘Bird’ Parker’s life. Capturing the trials and tribulations of a black musician in white America, this film takes an in-depth look at the multi-faceted world of the jazz life — music, drink, drugs, racism, women, and indifference. Features Dick Gregory in the key role as Richie ‘Eagle’ Stokes, with Don Murray playing a down-and-out professor. Adapted from the John A. Williams’ novel “Night song”.

results.title: All change please
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
“All change please. That’s what they say when the train is at the last station.” Diana Anderson began her journey around 23 years ago when she moved on to her husband’s family farm in north-west Victoria. Worked on for generations, Diana and Choco improved and changed the farming business, raising their two boys and enjoying the life for almost 23 years. That is until they were confronted with the distressing news the family partnership was to be sold. For Diana this was the end of one journey and the start of another - a new beginning.
